Need to pay everything for sport usage as a staff. Gym hour open too late.

review_title: Great environment and strong research assets within the organisation. Culture is conducive for thinking and self-improve
job_title: Research Assistant in Clementi New Town,
pros: Well-known name and reasonable location at the South-west of Singapore. Ample parking space at reasonable monthly rate that is pocket friendly
cons: Depending on your role within the organisation, it may be hard to progress beyond. Considering the fact that it is not as profit driven as other companies, moving on to an opportunity in a profit company may not be smooth.

review_title: Post-Docs and Research Fellowships - A good opportunity but know the downsides
pros: NUS has some excellent opportunities for post-doctoral and advanced fellowships in the social sciences and the humanities. These fellowships are offered by colleges, departments and special institutes and are great opportunities for junior scholars to complete research programs in the region. The caliber of intellectual engagement at NUS is very high, and the university is committed to becoming the premier university in SEA. Fellows will generally find a collegial atmosphere that is supportive of innovative research. Research money is available and most fellows are permitted (and expected) to travel for fieldwork for part of their fellowship. Life in Singapore is pleasant and safe and it is easy to access the rest of the region, East Asia, and Australia from the island.
cons:
The cost of living in Singapore is exorbitant and NUS generally does not provide faculty housing or substantive housing allowance for junior fellows and postdoctoral researchers, instead prioritizing more senior and 'big name' researchers and providing them with housing. The average cost of renting a public housing block apartment in Singapore now stands at between 50-70% of a post-doctoral fellow's monthly salary (including the paltry housing allowance provided for foreign fellows). Single fellows can compensate by sharing housing with other fellows or renting a room, but married fellows or those with children are increasingly finding it difficult to make ends meet. 

Fellows doing research on Singaporean life (particularly politics) need to be aware of some potential for restrictions on intellectual freedom. 

Singapore is a pleasant place to live with many amenities for families. It is, however, somewhat sterile and the cost of amenities (particularly alcohol - which is subject to a 100%+ luxury tax) can be steep. Families with children will need to consider schooling options - public school is an option although it may not be appropriate for all children and work permit holders have lowest priority in the school system. Many excellent international schools are located in Singapore, however these tend to be quite expensive and NUS does not provide a tuition subsidy.

pros: There is work-life balance in some departments,
cons:
Very restrictive and bureaucratic. There is a lot of red tape in being able to get things done. Mindset of bosses here are archaic and they are stuck in their ways, not open to new ways of doing things. There is no mentoring of staff to help staff progress.
There is no flexibility to work from home. Shuttle buses and canteens are crowded. If staff are allowed to work from home once a week, it will ease the strain on the infrastructure.

review_title: Top brains, they work hard - normal University constraints
pros: Amongst the 40 top tier universities of the world...  with a clear agenda to go higher.   Easy to understand why NUS will get better - the city of Singapore is a nice place to be... The University is working hard to recruit the best research talent -and student talent.
cons: Classical old world governance and management  - but if you can survive - you can make a great difference!  All not-for-profit universities have weak management... but there are real opportunities to make a difference - because the faculty strength is 100% there.

review_title: Institute of Systems Science (ISS) - High staff turnover!
pros: Nice campus albeit somewhat inaccessible,  decent HR policies and benefits.
cons: Each department/institute/school operates independently hence culture varies greatly.  ISS  staffed with too many old ex-public sector types at senior levels who  have little empathy for the people under them while they reap the rewards of their staff's hard work.

review_title: It's fun to work with fresh graduates, and have plenty of time to do things you like.
A great learning opportunity for new graduates, highly beneficial to mid-career and family-oriented employees.
pros: NUS is huge. Every faculty, central office is an individual organisation and culture on its own. Therefore you can't use your experience for the whole NUS. In general, NUS offers good training opportunity, nice HR benefits, systematic and clear career path if you plan to stay in long term.
cons:
For a faculty, the treatment for different categories of staff is widely varied. Most important is faculty staff, followed by admin staff, then research assistant staff. This usually affects the staff's morale.
Salary increment is relatively modest, career advancement can be slow.

pros: Convenient for small families, very safe and easy to adapt, good research opportunities, good salary, very good living conditions, well located, best place for expats in Asia probably.
cons: Heavy work load, high demand for publications, hard to get tenure, not so good social interaction, in general students may be less enthusiast and active than in other regions (Europe, US. Latin america, etc)

pros:
Firstly, let me begin by saying that NUS is HUGE. There are many many different professors, each of whom act like minor Barons, running their labs as they each see fit. Hence, your exact work conditions will depend heavily on who your manager/professor is. There are some good bosses. There are also some terrible bosses.

My best advice is to talk to those already working under this professor, to get a sense of their style.
cons: Leaving aside the issue of what your boss is like: As with any large bureaucracy, sometimes the NUS admin department can be a bit... slow in processing things.

pros:
Research funding is generous, seems stable. Food on campus quite OK. Nice location in Singapore. University seems to be on upwards trajectory.
Salary quite good on international scale, though not so good on Sg scale.
cons: Pace of expansion is fast, some poor hirings. Awful paperwork and admin burden, some research support staff flaky (although some are good). Singapore is a bit hot. Some profs think they are god.

review_title: Fantastic University.. On its way to be the Stanford of Asia
pros: Great work environment. Good benefits. Word class colleagues. NUS is on its way to being among the very best in the world. The resources available to do research are amazing. The students are also extremely bright.
cons: Can be a little bureaucratic. Lots of paper trail for everything. Much better terms for expat faculty compared to local faculty. Singaporeans do not recognize the value of this institution.

pros:
Work Life Balance
Family Oriented Culture
Good leave benefits (21 days), Parent care leave, childcare leave..
Transfer to other departments relatively easy
Career progression
cons:
Poor remuneration compared to stat boards or mministries
Lack of 13th month bonus for E&P staff
Only performance bonus available
Reporting officers a.k.a Deanery members review and rank staff but are not able to fight for staff

pros: Good source of income while studying, and teaching helps to solidify your skills. You get a lot of freedom in your work,  and it feels good to help the next batch of students learn. The hourly rate is decent and the hours are generally manageable. Fellow tutors that I've worked with were all friendly and willing to lend a hand.
cons: Balancing school and work can get difficult towards the end of semester, and it's a commitment so you cannot give up halfway.

pros: Flexible working hours, no much stress, good support from seniors and colleagues, good safety control and  equipment management, a lot of available resource such as articles, experiment materials
cons: a lot of experiments and lab work, need to work for long hours in the lab when project deadline and workshop approach, need to frequently report to supervisor with very detailed progress which requires a lot of time to prepare weekly report

pros:
School environment

Freedom to decide on project approach
cons:
People are suffering from technophobia (very dependent on IT team to do tasks in the system on their behalf)

Work in silos (do not view IT projects as strategic and do not bother preparing and giving full participation and requirements)

Felt no different from a vendor because every meeting is about reporting progress

Superior "attacks" his/her own team in front of HOD instead of understanding the situation and work things out.

Slow progression

Work/life balance is compromised due to compulsory duties required on a number of after office hours activities

review_title: Completed my PhD and worked as a post-doc here (Faculty of Engineering)
pros:
1.	By and large, in-hand salary can be slightly higher than most other places.
2.	The university is well-funded and the general facilities within the university are good. Depending on the supervisor and laboratory, many of the facilities are world-class. This is highly subjective though, don’t go by the university rankings, try to know as much as possible about the professors you aspire to work with before coming here. I have been quite fortunate in this regard.
3.	People in general are diligent and carry out their duties well.
4.	Intellectual quality of students and staff is generally good.
5.	NUS is a well-known and well respected university.
cons:
1.	Don’t be misled by the rankings. I really don’t think NUS deserves to be that high on the list.
2.    Other than universities and A-Star institutes, there are few industries in and around Singapore who wish to hire PhDs.
2.	There aren't many courses worth the time and effort. Quality of teaching is poor. While undergraduate course-material is quite alright, professors don’t know how to teach well. Post-grad course material in most cases does not add any value. I don’t recommend anyone to come to NUS (or any other institute in Singapore) to do their Bachelors or Masters.
3.	NUS (and perhaps Singapore) is hyper-obsessed with safety, to the point of being counter-productive in day-to-day laboratory activities.

pros: State-of-the-art working environment, flexible working style, suitable for those ready for retirement, fixed working hour
cons: Less staff welfare because HR claimed we are charity organisation, limited in-house training development as management cut cost, no staff appreciation (academic/PhD holders given more weigh, hold top positions, higher remuneration). Not a first-choice organisation to join for fresh graduate, high performer as no learning & developing opportunity. Still too much bureaucratic and strange bell curve on appraisal system (especially executive not backed by union, no 13th month), miserable bonus/salary adjustment (cover inflation rate only).

pros: Good support to whatever you want to do and gain independence in your research work. Many opportunities to be exposed to the international research field.
cons: There is no clear measure to track the progress of a Ph. D. student. The modular system just does not quite work to measure the success of a Ph. D.

pros: It's pretty fun listening to other students go at each other, you get to learn more about a subject and better access to a professor, you have quite a bit of power over students depending on your prof.
cons: Pay is non-existential, work might be heavy and conflict with your current studies, you might have to deal with pesky students and get a lot of calls for help especially around busy times

pros: Good work life balance. Can pursue areas of interest within project based on curiosity. Excellent core facilities and lab.
cons:
None so far. 

I don't complain about things that does not affect my work performance, and nothing is affecting it yet.

review_title: my first job, the experience taught me a lot
pros: the university basically consists of dozens of faculties, and each faculty is made up of dozens of departments. and there are another dozen of teams working in one department. I was in one of the team. so the job experience really depends on which team you will be assigned to. close team work.
cons: varied cultures across different faculties, departments. only strong bonds within the team. very weak bonding reaching out to other teams in the same departmen

pros: Didn't see any pros. I mean, it's a well known university, but there are many well known ones, and NUS doesn't stand out too much from them in terms of working comfort or anything that adds value to the working life.
cons: Overly bureaucratized. For a research university one has to fill up endless forms and attend endless trainings, when am I supposed to do the actual research?

pros: Relatively flexible work environment. Good if you wish to not have to overwork. Loads of cheap and good food options on campus.
cons: Not rewarding for good performers as there too many employees who just want an easy life and retire there. Good performers end up doing all the work and there is not much differentiation in  compensation provided.

job_title: Research Fellow/Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Singapore
pros: Good reputation. Very good funding. State of the art infrastructures. World leading experts in most of the research fields.  Research with a strong lookout for applications. Good learning opportunities.
cons: Very long hours. Work/ life balance not so good. High pressure environment. Lack of common sense and fundamental knowledge at the lower resercher level. Lack of enough qualified personnel.

review_title: Corporatised but still not much workplace change.
pros: The government is funding the university and there is no layoff so far. The increment and bonus are dependent on the country economic growth.
cons: Performance appraisal is subjected to some unknown quota and usually normalized across the department. Salary Increment is small as it is a big organization to be sustainable in the long term and promotion is slow.

pros: NUS offers a competitive scholarship which includes full tuition fee and monthly allowance for 4 years of candidature. Depending on the supervisor, scholars are sometimes subsidized for overseas scientific conferences.
cons: Competitive and stressful environment. Long lab hours for experimental projects. Candidates are expected to pass two qualifying examinations and publish certain number of journal papers in world-class journals in order to graduate.

review_title: Learned a lot although more could be expected
pros: Rich resources for research and self-learning, good opportunities to participate in overseas exchange programmes, advanced facilities and excellent living conditions
cons: Not many really good professors, administrative office not very efficient, many restrictions as an international student,  not very good career preparations

pros: usually, the office/ office rest rooms are cozy. because of as a research scientist or assistant, one is easy to get touch with research equipment or instruments, so may gain more experience in one area.
cons: often job offers are coming with contract, so need to recontract if PI has continuous funding, ortherwise have to look for another position (but as I said in Pros, one can have experience with that research area, it should be easier to secure one than those fresh grads.)

review_title: I do a civil servant's job for none of  the benefits but all the disadvantages of being a civil servant
pros:
1. More freedom than the corporate world - in a university almost anything goes...
2. Less backstabbing and a friendly working environment
3. Flexibility in working arrangements
cons:
1. Salary cannot compete with the private sector
2. Staff come and go - a lot of contract-basis employment
3. You can get "too comfortable" working there

review_title: Could be required to work over time.
pros: Foods are cheap, lots of canteens in the campus.
cons: Some assistant professors may push you very hard. Because getting tenure in NUS, especially in computing, is very difficult for the faculties in recent years. Some research fellows and phd students are pushed to work 12 hours per day for at least 6 days a week.

job_title: Senior Assistant Brand Manager in Clementi New Town,
pros: I am a results-oriented, high-energy, hands-on professional, with 20 years of successful record of accomplishments in the Build Environment sector like Building/Project/Fire Safety Management.
cons: There is always a certain degree of uncertainty when changing jobs:  The last thing I want is to start a job search again if the grass won’t be greener with a new employer. I want to make sure a new opportunity provides me with the things I found lacking in my current job.

pros: PhD studies in NUS usually comes with financial support in the form of monthly stipend for students. Supervision quality varies depending on who you work with. Excellent support for research resources.
cons: Ingrained individualistic culture, lack of collegiality. As a graduate student who intends to work actively with the faculty members, I feel that I am fending for myself all the time. Probably has to do with the incentive structure for faculty in NUS.

pros:
- 21 days annual leave (heard that academic staff has 28 days leave)
- Gym/Library facility 
- Friendly staff
- Affordable food prices in canteens
- Work life balance 
- Staff concession for taking Master degree in NUS (benefits for perm staff within NUS)
cons:
- Rigid bureaucracy/management (must go through alot of barriers) to get things done. 
- Lack of career advancement in my dept 
- Dept management did not endorse certain aspects of my continuing professional development. (Pay out of my own pocket and took my own leave)

review_title: Lots of learning experience in the r&d sector
pros: I was lucky to have a very patient prof in a small start up lab. As such, i was able to work alongside with my prof and learnt alot of stuff directly from him. There are lots of room for self-experimentation as well.
cons: Lab experience varies from lab to lab. You really need to know your prof before you decide to work with them. Quite slow-paced research and might not be suitable for people in the faster-paced industry.

review_title: Many paid leave but lacklustre bonuses
pros: Relaxed environment with good bosses and colleagues. Food is affordable since it’s in a university. Lots of labs around meaning collaborations are easier to arrange.
cons: The bonus is abysmal, and the salaries are Low if you don’t negotiate for it. If you’re looking to be at the cutting edge of R&D, the slow pace can sometimes be frustrating.

review_title: A good way to grow your knowledge
pros: The TA job can make you very familiar with the course you are teaching. You can improve yourself in communication skills and presentation skill. Besides it is a good job because it is just part-time, you can be a TA when doing your research as a M.Sc student or a Ph.D student.
cons: Sometimes professors could be really demanding, ask you to finish a lot of tasks within a short time.

pros:
- Work-life balance
- Cheap canteen food
cons:
- Overall, poor upper management in NUS Enterprise, which probably explains why recent hires generally leave within 2 plus years.
- Lack of proper resource planning for projects, everything is mostly "on fire"/last minute. This also leads to some projects being shelved and never picked up again. 
- Too much focus on marketing, lack of focus on whether the services/resources being offered to start-ups are actually competitive (compared to other incubators).
- Poor infrastructure (e.g. problems crop up in building facilities often)

pros:
Availability of high tech instruments 
Good country location for those who like to travel around Asia and Australia
cons:
Rigid culture in the work place and Singapore 
Access to high tech instrument are limited to "who your manager is" 
For those who work in R&D, expect severe delay (2 weeks) on chemical procurement as all chemicals must be imported from US or Europe.
Expect a majority of people would not share information for the purpose of common goal
Low work ethics and interpersonal values at management level. I have seen employees getting their termination notice BY E-MAIL ! or without prior review performance/discussion.

pros:
Flexible working hours.  Well known and respectful employee.

I'm extreme lucky to have a wonderful supervisor, who cares a lot about my welfare, career development, etc. He is willing to help at any time. Years back when I was trying to get my wife's dependent pass, my salary was too low to apply to ICA. He really fought for me and got me a huge increase. I'm always grateful.
cons:
Short of office for post-doc researchers in Mechanical Engineering Department.
Lack of career opportunities

pros: The resources supporting research at NUS are unlike anything I've encountered at other universities (primarily in the US). State of the art equipment, numerous grant opportunities, and supportive staff make it an outstanding place to get ahead in research.
cons: Work-life balance is not a major focus of faculty or research staff. Moving to Singapore from abroad and beginning work at NUS is made surprisingly challenging by an intensive series of bureaucratic hoops at both the university and national levels.

review_title: pros and cons of working in NUS
pros:
reasonable grant opportunity, 
overall student quality is good, 
good salary increase if performance is rated good (but start salary is really low), 
close to China (if you want to visit it a lot)
cons:
bad weather, too hot for any outdoor activities in daytime
a lot of micro-management down to almost every details
need to document almost everything

review_title: I have been working here since my PhD
pros: Working as a research fellow, you have the freedom to manage your own work well and prepare for the next phrase of your career. The working time is flexible, but this also means that you can easily work over time.
cons: It's a contract job. If you don't have a plan for yourself, this job does not help you much in the long term.

pros: Lush jungle campus, calm atmosphere for research, world-class rankings across numerous scientific disciplines, and rapid response time for technical or IT issues.
cons: A focus on "by the book" metrics, "key performance indicators", and other markers that, while they may work well in business settings, do not necessarily facilitate the research enterprise.

pros: stable job, good company to seek sponsorship for further studies, very supportive of staff who further improves themselves.
cons: Forget about market value pay, forget about career progression. Forget about your ambitions. Forget about speedy processes. Forget about adopting changes.

review_title: Good for folks with family (Admin staff with academic department)
pros:
- Great work-life balance. Good amount of leave/childcare leave for Exec & Professional Staff.
- Medical and insurance benefits.
- Reasonable pay. (Not the best. But the pros make up for it.)
- Cheap food. Great variety across the huge campus.
cons:
- Slow career progression. Or there might not be much potential for progression.
- Conservative admin processes. Lots of room for improvement.

pros: family orientated, flexible in terms of leaves, time-off etc. Bosses are compassionate and general benefits are alright.
cons: low increment, low salary, very slow promotion. More of a retirement job than a job that you can do to keep a family alive.

pros:
- You will have accessed to fairly well-equipped laboratories
- You are given significant freedom to purse your research interests
- You can have amber exposure to the industry
cons: - Meeting KPIs (e.g., quantity of publications) can be rather stressful, which inhibits the willingness to embark on a large scale project.

review_title: Great colleagues, shaky processes. Job rotation could be better (Admin).
pros: Working with my colleagues makes life easier when a team spirited approach is taken. Faculty brings up the value of the organisation.
cons: Admin processes still need more work. Recognition of personal efforts to improve oneself (i.e. further studies) should be acknowledged and worked upon.

pros: Good hours, not much politics. Minimal red tape, quite a lot of freedom to go beyond scope of syllabus in class teaching. student feedback system forces you to do job well. Can get award if you get high scores.
cons: Not much career growth prospects. Many teaching assistants see it as temporary job for side income during post-graduate studies

pros: NUS is more mature in terms of everything (compared to NTU) such as administration, formalities, lab management, etc.
cons: Comments regarding a postdoc job are very case by case, depending on the PI, the lab, and the topics you are working on. So it is more like an issue with the research rather than with the institution. No work/life balance for a postdoc research fellow if you are pursuing further in research, but that's personal choice though.

pros: The working culture in NUS is quite friendly, and less politics. It also provides many good learning opportunities to improve self's skills.
cons: Many positions are contract-based, faculties, teaching and research staff are all need to face stress of renewing contract every year or every three years.

review_title: Nice working environment and good place to engage in world class research
pros:
-Good funding scenario for the project and great facilities
-Competitive environment
-Friendlier colleagues
cons:
-Salary and compensation a bit on the lower side (at least in my department) compared to the market trends.
-very little opportunity to expand beyond the current job scope
-Long working hours
-Very tiring paper works and bureaucracy for trivial things.

pros:
Flexible working time and schedule if you have a nice boss. 
Very friendly working environment!
Good facility for research.
cons:
Relatively low salary considering the high living cost in Singapore. Really low salary compared to industry.
Not very good school reputation for the academic development compared to the US top universities.

pros: The benefits are similar to working at any university, access to a gym, pool, tennis courts, and libraries.
cons: I am not originally from Singapore, but the health insurance policy was very poor. I have not been able to fully understand what is and is not covered. Preexisting conditions are not covered unless you have been an employee for more than 1 year. The system for filing an insurance claim in not very clear.

review_title: Good Work/Life Balance, Median Salary Range, Very Poor Management of Admin/Exec Staff
pros: Most of the faculty and students are great to work with. Very good work/life balance and quite a pro-family place.
cons: The office politics can be out of hand. Some departments are very poorly managed. Very high turnover rate. Management of admin and executive staff needs a lot of work.

pros: The position allows for working with different research centres within the university and is rewarding because of the role it plays in technology commercialisation.
cons: Most of the technology under research and development is still at the early-stage and not all might lead to a commercial success story. Other than that, the University itself is a great place to work.

pros: NUS provides the teaching assistant with a lot of help and guidance. Payment is also not bad for a part-time job.
cons: Sometimes the work needs to be done may exceed the total number of allocated hours. Therefore, be prepared to work extra from time to time.

review_title: Good place for doing my own research
pros:
Cheap food expenses in the campus-wide.
Good employer for living in Singapore for foreigners.
Friendly admin staff.
Moderately good insurance benefits.
More than enough annual leaves.
cons:
No accessible MRT station by walk. (Kent Ridge MRT is far from most of the working area, but close to the dormitories and lecture halls.)
Canteens are working based on Students' life patterns, and many canteens are under construction these days.
No bonus or Annual wedge.

pros: You can save costs on food as there are a lot of canteens around NUS. Routine work. Salary is based on tier so it wouldn't be too bad.
cons: Minimal training, no proper feedback or review on individual work to help employees. There are a lot of parties involved which is dragging the time taken just to complete one task. Given that central department is always so busy, it is difficult to seek help from them.

pros:
- Pretty flat hierarchy
- Great peers, great colleagues--best part of the job. 
- Wonderful students, a really bright, diverse, friendly bunch
- Good benefits
- Good food at all the hawker centers
- Good location.
cons:
- Departments sometimes don't communicate to each other, leads to some conflict, some confusion, some overlapping work. 
- Huge bureaucracy--takes a long time for paperwork to get done. 
- More communication between people needed.

pros: Family Friendly, good colleagues at a working level, not much OT expected without compensation of time off.  Exposure to exciting start-ups and inspiring students.
cons: Poor paymaster, unclear leadership, management did not have a good understanding of on-the-ground ops, HR and Finance are sticklers for by-the-books ops with no flexibility and poor communication with other departments.

pros: Well-accepted worldwide, especially in the asia-pacific region, and world class facilities. It offers a quite comprehensive and balanced education experience. And there is enough teaching training required for research student, which is a great advantage for seeking jobs after graduation
cons: The support for attending conferences and participating in long-term research programs outsides Singapore is really limited.  Some requirement for research staff is really burdensome.

review_title: Good overall experience for research jobs
pros: Good atmosphere, flexible working hours and very good employee benefits. I would recommend fresh graduates to try out these jobs.
cons: Few long-term positions for researchers, career path is relatively limited. Most of the jobs are temporary and employees have to turn to industry at some time.

pros: Good work-life balance. There is autonomy to pursue work that is interesting provided a clear value proposition is shown to bosses.
cons: There is a glass ceiling if you do not have a PhD. Maybe should remove it for non-faculty positions. The bonus is pretty bad.

pros: Good environment for researchers. Usually you have enough freedom to pursue your own idea. Although it also depends on your supervisor.
cons: Applying visa can take quite some time, but that is not a problem of the university, rather a government issue. GAP requirement is 416 hours, too many.

job_title: Research Fellow in Clementi New Town,
pros: - 28 days of annual leave
cons:
- Very bureaucratic and multi layer admin/process system for everything
- Poorly managed and administered admin system
- Lots of Redundant and Ridiculous admin policy
- Aged record keeping system. Extensive use of hardcopy forms for everything 
- lots of deadwood
- Lack of professionalism across all admin levels (e.g lab staff yelling/throwing forms around) 
- "Yes, you need THREE quotations" and "the lowest bid wins!!"
-  A very Old-fashioned and a rigid procurement system

review_title: It is my valuable experience working with NUS
pros: a very good university in the world and a very wonderful project which may extend my career in the future.
cons: The trainning and equipements need to be futher improved. On the other hand, the communication between team members also has a room to improve.

pros:
Long annual leave (starting from 18 days); 
Good working and recreational environment (near-free access to sports facilities, library), 
Good and cheap food, 
traffic is convenient with the new opening of Kent Ridge MRT station.
cons: Lower salary comparing to industry

review_title: Good for research, or doing PhD
pros: RA positions are widely available from many departments. There are really great professors you can work with.
cons: For a research assistant position, it is better if you want to do a PhD later, or you are really interested in doing research. Otherwise, it would be hard to motivate yourself doing research. The pay is lower than what you get in industry, and increases slow.

review_title: Flexible hours, fun to teach.. but compensation not so attractive
pros:
World renowned institution
Great staff - both academic colleagues and admin
Flexible hours - student contact time is not so demanding and the remaining work can be done anytime anywhere
Offices - 2 to a room!
Great way to support self during graduate studies
cons:
Pay is considerably low with negligible increments
Career growth is very slow - takes too long to move from being a TA to an instructor

review_title: It is good experience studying in NUS
pros:
nice campus, helpful supervisors, friendly working staff, and passionate students.
Some chance to learn modules from other faculties. 
Developing.
cons: career service needs to be stronger, especially for postgraduate students (PhD), many PhD students were recruited, but at the end, they have not many places to go as in SG, the positions that need PhD are relatively few.

review_title: poor culture and environment to work and learn in
pros: there is no pros in my opinion
cons: Poor leadership skills from the management, result-orientated, only cares about the end product. Management is demanding (depends which school), employees having poor work-life balance. If the management doesn't like you and / or is unable to control you, they will find ways to make you leave.

pros: NUS is a great place to do research because it has the right environment: smart, passionate and team player type of people, sufficient funds, responsive management. NUS is probably the highest ranked university in Asia and among the best in the world. It offers an opportunity to work with people having diverse cultural backgrounds.
cons: Sometimes I feel that facilities for recreation could be better.

pros: Free study environment, knowledgeable teachers and researchers you can discuss with. Facilities are also good.
cons:
some pressure, as a PhD student, it happens everywhere. But the writting QE is really 
unnecessary. Also you have a time limit to graduate. It is 5 years, good luck!

pros: The stipend of NGS scholarship is very high compared to the normal NUS research Scholarship. NGS also provide SGD4000 per year to support oversea travelling for academic conference. The NGS staff are very nice and they always consider for students.
cons: Compared to NUS research Scholarship, I can say NGS scholarship has no cons.

pros: The tasks are fairly easy but will give you a good learning opportunity. The supervisors and colleagues are great people too.
cons: The events are rather big scale, so minor mistakes can hinder the event flow. Although the supervisors will not reproach us but the event flow is important so we will feel bad for screwing up.

review_title: A high class university with well established facilities
pros: Well established facilities. Depending on your supervisor, you have the freedom to pursue your interest and work toward your research project. Employee has strong support from the administrative staff and colleagues.
cons: Depending on your supervisor, you may have very high pressure to push for your publications. You may stay in your comfort zone and do not get to explore the other career opportunities actively.

pros: very up-to-date research facilities. Good amount of research funding sponsored by the government. great work-life balance
cons: the HR process can be a bit slow due to the complicated admin system. Have to be very careful not to breach the numerous school policies while conducting research.

job_title: PhD Student in Woodlands New Town,
pros: Good campus in a beautiful and safe country. Good facilities and lab instruments.
cons: Just stay away from some of the Chinese and Indian supervisors. They have a very boss and employee culture in their groups.  So, the expectations are very high with no scientific help from the supervisor.

pros: Excellent health plan, flexible hours, 28 working days yearly leave. Great working environment. Greatly depends on the supervisor. I am one of the (lucky) ones to have an excellent boss that respects people's time and has reasonable deadlines and expectations. Excellent work life-balance.
cons:
Conditions greatly depend on the supervisor/boss.
Prospects for promotion basically non-existent. However, postdoc is just a temporary position, so this is not expected.
Conferences typically not supported.

pros: friendly working environment, nice boss and little infightings or back-stabbings. working hours are very flexible. can take a leave as long as one month each year with payment.
cons: there is limited upside potential of this work. The continuity of the work depends on the funding capabilities of the boss. So unassured.

pros: Well organized, friendly environment, flexible, good working attitude, good package in accommodation, low tax, good international environment
cons: Hot Singapore weather, high price to buy a car, a lot of document works which might not be necessary, high price in living if required US standard, Difficult to be promoted, Risky in career (firm six year evaluation system)

pros:
Good facilities
Freedom to work on one's own projects
International recognition
Knowledgeable supervisors
Chance to collaborate with external researchers
Generous pay (but it stays the same).
cons:
Hectic work schedule - no work-life balance. Expected to work at all times.
Too much emphasis on producing publications, simply for the sake of publications.

pros: Job responsibility is stable. And it is a flexible environment, the time of work is flexible, no quite a lot of meetings, you do have some time to work on what you want to do.
cons: There is a pressure for weekly update. Most of the time, research work will tend to fail instead of give you desired results. It is a bit hard to have satisfied results to present every week.

pros: Good school with excellent facilties and has really launched itself on the global scene. Very good teachers and classes were productive
cons: Needs to be more acceptive, student culture is not what i am accustomed to. Just feels a bit kiddy. However this is just my humble opinion.

pros: I have very good experience in microbiology related work especially handled BSL2 facility work and pathogen-bacteria/virus more than  7 years worked in this area at NUS.
cons: I am a passionate scientist who is looking for research position in your lab. I have abundant experience in hands on lab, running a few a projects and proposals.

pros:
cheap canteen food but crowded during school days
work life balance.
boss are not pushy or micro manage as long as things are done. 
plenty of leave and standard benefits
AWS pretty good > 1 month excluding 13th month
cons: slow paced. hard to move up unless your supervisor push you but still dependent on hq decision.

review_title: Please do not apply for the institute manager position
pros: Overall as an university it provides great medical benefit and number of leaves with added parental care leave.
cons: Depends on department to institute and centers..Cold environment for my institute where I worked...all the directors position are hold by the Profs who are part time who you hardly see them few times a month. Overwhelming heavy responsibility to lead by yourself without the director presence and overloading unnecessary of the administration staff without the proper governance and structure within the institute

review_title: Retirement position with little lateral movement
job_title: Program Manager in Clementi New Town,
pros: Generally stable, no major changes to role and position. If you’re in a a faculty you’re job is very secured.
cons: Very little career development from human resource. Most of the time staff have to find your own development path and they are usually not provided.  If you’re not from academia there’s no chance for senior mgmt. no internal promotion

pros: Decent benefits and lots of food options.
cons: Poor working culture where people loves to speak but asking others to do the job.

review_title: World-class educational institution and great place to work and live
pros:
Convenient transportation,
All kinds of free facilities for staff and students
Nice canteens
Responsible and efficient administrative staff
cons:
Lack of accommodation
Lack of flexibilities among the admin personnel (well, it's common in Singapore)
Some politics I don't really get
No permanent positions available for research staff or even for some faculties, which is quite challenging for the employees to be fully committed to the job.

pros:
NUS is major brand in Asian, perhaps worldwide context, adding to the prestige and glamour working in NUS.
Starting salary was good, and higher than average market rate
Good working environment.
Nice, closely knitted, family-like colleagues
cons:
Slow career progression, took me 4 years to get promoted
Got award, but did not affect my performance grading at all
Limited learning opportunities
Management does not know ground well

pros:
Flexible benefits.
Varied food choices for lunch.
cons: The university has a history of springing academics into management positions for which they are thoroughly unequipped. For example, my department's main role was to partner foreign universities in exchange arrangements and encourage students to sign up for exchange programmes. However, we were first led by a professor of dentistry, who was then succeeded by a professor of linguistics. Until today, I'm still not sure how having good teeth or a frighteningly extensive vocabulary helped our work.

pros: the good academic setting, flexible hours, can do relevant research to further own research interests, no office politics
cons: sometimes have to do tedious work like collect primary material, some tasks are too simple and repetitive, like photocopy, scanning etc. not challenging

review_title: Collaborated with 4 team members to develop a start-up for LED lighting for maximum value creation
pros: NUS has been ranked among the best in both Singapore and Asia mainly by the QS rankings; which is based heavily on anonymous surveys on universities reputation.
cons: Currently, it has seven overseas colleges at major entrepreneurial hubs in Shanghai and Beijing (China), Israel, India, Stockholm (Sweden), Silicon Valley and Bio Valley (US).

pros: NUS is a vibrant workplace with professionals from across a few different fields. Colleagues are from all over the world.
cons: Location is a little further off to the west. Canteens can get very crowded and busy especially during the start of each academic year.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bukit Merah Estate,
pros: Able to provide enough information for undergraduate students to review their future employees' company details and the requirements of current offering
cons: The job offering format is not really well organised,   the date of positions posting is not in order

pros: You get a Ph.D. in 4 years. facilities are good. Supervisor depends on luck. and i really got lucky.
cons: very lonely, nobody helps you most of the time. Some Supervisors really pressure alot. Almost no choice in choosing your topic. most of the time you just do what supervisor is working upon. Well this can be a pros if you dont have any idea of your own.

pros: Working with people from diverse cultures, and good bosses who were appreciative of their staff's efforts. They generally follow a structured work process and there was autonomy at work. Colleagues were generally sincere, helpful, and were focused on getting the job done.
cons: High workload and not-so-favourable pay package. There could be red tape at times. The aforementioned pros do not apply to all schools within NUS.

pros: To be specific, I am working towards my MPP at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy (LKYSPP), a graduate branch of the NUS. It is a fantastic school with incredible faculties, admission and administration teams, and of course students. You will make amazing friends while you are there.
cons: Some of the classes are incredibly rigorous so it is essential to come to every class well-prepared.

pros:
Easy environment to work in. 
Politics can be navigated with some effort (not as cutthroat). 
Massive organisation so there is room to switch roles, learn and progress upwards in one's career.
cons: Archaic - needs to move into the future. Kudos for new efforts that aim to push us further along and make the system more efficient.

pros:
- Clean and safe environment
- Organized and efficient
cons:
- High costs of living
- Stressful environment (specific to my prof)
- You may experience harassment, yelling, may get insulted by your prof, denied holiday leaves, forced to work overtime and no weekends and still no university law to protect you

pros: Standard work scheduling, quite relaxing, supporting professors and PHDs doing research work. exposure to new theory and concepts overall enjoyable
cons: too relaxed. there is not much of work that i need to do, project progress was slow over the research internship period.

pros: Just a name which promotes itself well.
cons: Shifting to new residences on campus required and paycut of more than 25%. Take it or leave it attitude and zero accomodation and flexibility regarding academic staff's needs. Preference for locals over expats. Low salaries in comparison, no inflation compensation over years.  Very intransparent and unfriendly HR officers, which can hardly be accessed. A lot of frustration and not keeping promises regarding tenure, promotions, salary. According to senior management, staff is meant to leave any ways after some years. Dictate housing and living conditions. Very, very frustrating employer!!!

review_title: fulfilling work, but difficult career advancement
pros: doing research work in a discipline that i love is very fulfilling. encouraging professors and colleagues. okay-ish pay. good work environment.
cons: the travel time to work was very very long, almost an hour for me by car. career advancement opportunities were limited, as is much the case in academia

pros: Facilities are world class, at least in most of the labs, classrooms, lecture halls etc., compared to a public university in the US where I spent 6 months.
cons: This is definitely NOT a place where they encourage you set your path in academia, nor do they provide much help or encouragement if you wish to. Some faculty members are of the lowest quality.

review_title: Could be great depending on the team you are in
pros: I had an excellent boss who encouraged the team to constantly challenge ourselves and innovate. This person made sure that we didn't have to deal with any of the red-tape usually associated with large organisations such as NUS so that we could do our work efficiently and effectively.
cons: I do not have any comments on this.

pros: Nice working environment, and friendly staff. The professors and lecturers in general treat their teaching staff very well, and are ready to offer help as and when needed.
cons: More training could be provided to the non-local graduate students who are aiming to be a member of the teaching staff. Their communication skills and ability to be effective in the classroom can sometimes be sorely lacking.

pros: Flexibility, Student and staff friendly, convenience, high class education, extra curricular, sports activities are very good. Excellent student service centre
cons: Very high stress levels, extreme competitive environment, very hot and humid climate, expect more results from students than from staff

review_title: Good opportunities and open minded collaborators
pros: Jobs timings and requirements are flexible but it really depends on your Professor but it is a good place for open minded collaborators.
cons: Salary and compensation would be considered low compared to jobs in Industry so you might feel left behind from your peers.

review_title: Working as an executive in NUS
pros: You get to know about what state of the art technologies or research projects are. You get cheaper food in the canteen compared to that outside the campus.
cons: The bureaucratic structure is too rigid. To get a thing done, you need to go through so many approval and in the end it is sometimes too late when the action is taken.

pros: There is considerable work life balance, and colleagues will seldom touch you after work hours.
cons: Management sometimes gives confusing instructions and impressions, resulting in staff being confused as well.

pros: flexible working hours, great teaching assistants, great facilities, great working hours, great to average working colleagues, great toilets and what nots
cons: bad management, bad weather, management do not care about older professors, do not value them as much as younger professors.

pros: A very focused course, which deals with the discipline of Real Estate, but skills can be acquired and transferable to other forms of business.
cons: Time management is crucial if you want to do well in the course, as there are projects after projects and this means you have to be able to work with different people and accommodate for each other's time.

review_title: Depends on research groups, it may be sometimes too stressful
pros: Some of the research groups have top publications, if you are really keen to do research and can work insanely hard, it is a good starting point.
cons: Some of the professors are too demanding when supervising Phd students

pros: I have been a full time student here in the last 9 years. My overall experience was positive. Staff and faculty members are friendly. Fair and transparent environment.
cons: Nothing really. It has been tough, competitive, and stressful, but that was probably dependent on your own aims and standards.

review_title: Admin staff is of least priority in NUS
pros:
You are able to leave work on time usually if you are not involved in any promotion activities or events which happens after working hours.  

Some departments have less work while some have lots of work. Depends on how your boss fight off the work or transfer the work to other departments. 

Good place for people who can talk a lot, be very friendly to senior management but not necessary need to do the work.
cons: More than enough to write a 5-page essay. Join at your own risk.

review_title: Discrimination between native Singaporean and foreigner
pros: Good junior faculties are around. Singapore is a good place to explore South Asia.
cons: The system at NUS is not transparent. There is a significant discrimination of treatment to foreigners here.  In our department, there are 6 assistant professors applying for promotion. There is only 1 native guy, whose record is not outstanding, passing.  The system here is only good for ones who were born in Singapore. It is certainly not a good place for foreigner junior faculties to develop their careers.

pros: The Hub for the region with many job opportunities, I guess.
cons: The climate is less international than one would think. Pressure is high and Profs practice closed door policies...even if the group next door is working on the same topic, collaborations are not encouraged. The climate for graduate researchers is extremely harsh. High pressure on the Profs that is passed on down the line.

review_title: Great learning ground with a conducive working pace
pros:
Work, life and family friendly
Caring colleagues and conducive pace to learn
Lots of experienced colleague that you can network and learn from.
cons: Not much career progression since it is has a rather flat organisational structure with the professors filling up most of the top management positions.

review_title: Very good learning and teaching experience!
pros: Nice working environment, friendly professors and lecturers are ready to offer help whenever needed, and the students are very bright, pleasant, and eager to learn.
cons: More training should be provided to non-local graduate students who are teaching, and there is a significant pressure when it comes to workload.

pros: Good environment for students. The research relationship between the faculty members and students is generally good.
cons: The majority of Engineering graduate students are from China. It would be good if it can be more diverse. Not sure how it is in other faculties.

pros: State of the art research tools at the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. I was able to do my research easily.
cons: None. I was working under an assistant professor, and i did not enjoy the high-stressed environment to help him churn out papers , although i did enjoy the process of exploring novel research.

review_title: Good work environemt, More or less depends upon which faculty / dept you are moving into in NUS
pros: 28 Paid leaves in a calendar year! & Medical insurance is decent. In case of hospitalaization we are in a better ward.
cons: Unless we are in admin positions or full time academic positions, we are not entitled to 13th month salary which is mandate in singapore

review_title: Personal opinion: projects going on slow sometimes
pros: In terms of research, lots of valuable research resources from various research institutes and professors.
cons: The institute i worked at did not encourage collaboration, and there are a lot of paper trails. I feel like most of the time I am writing emails instead of doing research or projects.

review_title: Flexible working hours and get an overview of how research work is carried out in tertiary institutions
pros: The job gives flexible working hours and I am allowed to work from home. Furthermore, colleagues are friendly and helpful.
cons: At times, there is a lack of guidance. This is partly due to the fact that we work out of the office.

review_title: Not a bad place to work in
pros: You get to be hands on in almost everything. Meaning you get to be exposed to multiples responsibilities.
cons: You will be a "jack of all trades master of none" here. Slow in career growth. Limited career progression.

pros: Working at your own pace.
cons: Vague directions. Happened to have a female prof who is emotionally and mentally unstable when it come to decision making at work.

pros: Stable environment. Many opportunities for research and grant calls (provided your work is in line with the Singapore Government outlook).
cons: Limited progression. Academia is tough. Not much staff benefit.

review_title: very good working environment, good people to work with  and learnt a lot form the job
pros: The work circle consists of some of the smartest people and it is really stimulating to work with them
cons: there are very few people you can get to know if you work in the lab all day long, sometimes its a bit lonely

review_title: Chose the wrong PI and lab, and suffered the next 2 years
pros: Very efficient admin. Much attention paid to personnel and lab safety. Good and accessible basic core facilities. Some opportunities for networking with other institutes through dept programmes/local conferences.
cons: Junior PI have too much discretionary power. Students aren't prepared for industry-relevant skills. Little to no collaboration with the clinic/other research institutes.

pros: beautiful campus, good facility, very silent because far away from city
cons: no ac provided in the weekend. so , if you want to ot, you have no place to go expcept for utown.

pros: Can have nice work life balance. 28 days off in a year and medical insurance covered. As a RA, you can learn a lot of techniques, publish papers and use this post as a stepping stone for good grad school.
cons: Not much career progression as a research assistant. Your position doesn't change even with years of experience.

pros: You get paid to study :)
cons: Your outlook varies depending on your supervisor. Some can be really fun to work with but there are numerous horror stories. I would strongly suggest spending some time vetting professors.

pros: Friendly environment within my faculty and even across faculties. NUS emphasises greatly on learning culture so there are always opportunities to upgrade your skills and to join workshops. It's a big organisations so staff benefits are pretty good. There are quite a few that focuses on improving the employees' well-being.
cons: None so far. Location not convenient to Easties.

pros: I'm an undergraduate student. I find working as a teaching assistant is a very good chance to improve communication skills and also a good chance to earn some pocket money.
cons: If you are an undergraduate student you can only be a teaching assistant in School of Computing. In other faculties they require you be at least a PhD candidate.

review_title: lots of freedom at work, good family-life balance, but poor career progression and stagnant pay
pros: in my research position, it is very much own-time-own-target. comfortable office and environment in general, supportive colleagues, good location
cons: limited motivation or challenges which after a while begins to dull your senses; limited career progression; stagnant pay;

pros: Able to work with bright students and the reputation of NUS convenient working with external (outside of NUS) partners.
cons: Indecisive leadership with senior management. Constant change in direction.

pros: Flexible, Talented co-workers, Great number of leaves. If you are in an interesting project and with a good Principal Investigator you are going to learn a lot.
cons: Bureaucratic, a little slow, uneasy power distribution between admin and academics. Low salaries. Needs a more focused approach to attract and retain talent instead of Hirt term research hires

review_title: Generally decent place for family oriented employment
pros: Generally flexible hours as long as with ability to deliver
cons: Limited opportunity for promotion due to institution wide bell curve

pros: Very good opportunities to pursue my research interests. Good support for collaboration. The campus has all the facilities I would ever ask for.
cons: Salary could be significantly higher. There could be better collaboration _between_ the different faculties. I some labs there is too much focus on publishing lots of papers instead of publishing good papers.

review_title: Great Working Environment and Work-Life Balance
pros: The working environment is nice. There is a lot of training opportunities for technical expertise as well as personal development. Office culture varies from office to office. People are generally nice. There is a number of health and wellness related lunchtime talks for staff.
cons: There is usually no promotion opportunity for research staff.

review_title: Good welfare with work-life balance but poor prospects, bureaucratic & myopic management
pros: Great for research and academic appointments; excellent work-life balance and welfare
cons: Poor prospects for appointments other than research & academic appointments; slow moving with huge bureaucracy and some turf mentality; some of  the senior management aloof from the rank and file with poor people's management skills

pros: There's a fair bit of annual leave for research staff (28 days). Depending on the supervisor, they can be also fairly flexible on when you can take the leave (project based and thus more flexible)
cons: Salary is not as much and bonus is all performance based (i.e. no 13th month bonus etc.). Salary increment is also quite limited.

pros: I work at the Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health. The upper management of our school is really supportive and very approachable. Nice working culture and environment.
cons: The direction of the university as a whole may not be always clear to all the faculties. But we are a huge university, to begin with.

pros: Flexible working hours. 42 hours work week from Monday to Friday. Friendly environment. Staff benefits are ok. Good work life balance.
cons: Pay increment is low. Promotion is slow. Career Progression is limited.

review_title: Dont expect a high pay here, but the work-life balance is a great plus.
pros:
Good work-life balance
Administration is fast and generally very helpful - eases the work that you do.
Bosses are great so far
The gym and all exercise amenities are here.
cons:
Not much of a promotion going on here
Salary is just enough to survive in Singapore with a family.

review_title: Working  in NUS as a research engineer in a company coordinated project
pros:
Good work-life balance: pay-leave up to 28 days/year
Competent colleagues who are willing to teach you and able to provide high quality of work,
Good transaction from school to company.
cons: No clear career path as a research engineer, if you are not going for a PhD degree.

pros:
Colleagues (as a whole university) are generally friendly, patient and helpful.
Established company.
Average compensation and benefits.
cons:
Department management may be dysfunctional/toxic, resulting in internal politics. Management backstabbing one another and gossiping is common.

Ethics of department management questionable, head can jump to conclusion and accuse staff without evidence, and just what was assumed based on what he knows about the "process", without apology when it it not the case he imagined. Staff are taught to feign ignorance to manipulate other colleagues.

pros: The working time is flexible, and the university environment is good. I like the staff here, very friendly and helpful.
cons: Compared with industry job, its salary is quite low. So it is most suitable for those who want to pursue Ph.D.

pros:
Excellent facilities and a lot of government investment in research.
One of the best universities for research in Asia.
Great location - Singapore.
cons:
Forget what the ratings say - it still cannot compare with the well-established universities in the US and Europe: uninspiring professors and mostly uninspired students.
Feels more like a school than a University.

pros: I worked in a research team as a Research Fellow. Those in my research team had very flexible working hours and the PI did not micromanage us. Overall, I had a really good experience
cons: The pay is a little low for most of us, I would have expected something better for people with PhDs.

pros: Depends on which team you are in. The ILO team is good and LS especially. Good work life balance. No. of vacation. steep learning curve. good start to for a fresher
cons: Salary, quite biased, Mismatch between the managements. hit saturation quite fast

review_title: Working at a subsidiary owned by NUS but with NUS pay scales (but no benefits)
pros: Good work life balance, intellectually fulfilling
cons: Slow progression, annual increment just matches inflation, no default one month bonus (all performace), HR not transparent, in general bonus cannot compare with the civil service at all

review_title: Good institution for pursuing your PhD degree
pros: I spent 4 years on study and research, besides my supervisor's patient and high -level instruction on research,  the school provide a convinient environment for students' living,  such as on campus clinic, various activities.
cons: Little communication betweent research groups.

pros: Working in a lab, it's expected to have more flexible lunch and working hours since timings of experiments can be unexpectedly long and impossible to change. Everyone understands that and is accepting of that fact.
cons: Pay is really low even compared to other research assistants in similar field. People can be really rule-abiding and resistant to change.

pros: Cheap canteen food, work-life balance, scenic environment, generous annual leave (up to 21 days).
cons: Mostly contract-based employment, limited to no medical benefits (for contract staff), lack of job security, bureaucratic red tape

review_title: I have studied MSC Bldg SC at SDE department of building.
pros: The program of study was quit good. There were various topics offered. The instructors were all experienced and research facilities are quite good.
cons: It is highly recommended  to study part time and work full time. Not all modules are offered in a yearly period.

review_title: Nice place to work, average salaries.
pros: Average packages. Well organized with helpful staff and equipment. Safe and convenient campus to work in. Nice for basic research. Very cheap and nice canteens.
cons: Science too basic. Welfare not that attractive. Hard to seek high future career development path, unless with very competent PIs. Lack close interaction with international researchers.

pros: Nice place to study and do research. Lot of funding available. Nice professors and students. Friendly  atmosphere and lot of good on-campus activities
cons:
Asian culture is too boring.
Job Scope is less
Research labs are bit old
House rent is too high

pros: Free and easy environment. Great people and ideas popping up everyday.
cons: Loose research management can mean unproductive work. Research experience is strongly related to your direct principle investigator, which means your research experience/anticipation may differ very much from what you anticipate from a high-ranking university/department. Choose your PI and research project wisely.

pros: Access to course, resources and facility
cons: A lot of bad things about NUS that I would like to say (peers, boss, admin, system), but they reserve the right to take back your degree if you say anything bad about them so I prefer not to elaborate. ( This itself  says a lot about NUS doesn't it )

review_title: It is a good experience, not easy, but fruitful.
pros: The university has good equipements to do research. The students are from different countries which gives you an opportunity to know different cultures.
cons: The work is not easy. Competetion is there. Research stuff usually needs to spend more time than in company to get some progress.

pros: Good environment generally, nice and smart people to work with, fairly flexible, no frequent overtime work, plenty of food options on campus
cons: Rigid structure, less incentive to excel, people not taking initiative, people tend to be mediocre, some politics in office, pay not so impressive

pros:
1. University is most famous in Singapore
2. Some schools have very high salary
3. Close to downtown
cons:
1. No bonus in some schools
2. EE is worse than EEE in NTU

pros:
Flexible working time. Can work from home. Friendly students and professor. 
Huge library, computer center. Many canteens. Shuttle bus. Free gym, sport facilites
cons: Lower pay. No AWS, bonus. No career path. Contract job. No count experiences when going outside to work.

review_title: a temporary job for a Phd graduate
pros: freedom of research, cheap food court, library, gym..a lot of resources
cons: most RA jobs are given by supervisors to their PhD student. the payment is very low even after the student has get the PhD degree. Supervisor has a lot of excuses to not give you a proper pay.

pros: Very friendly and welcoming staff. They understand the schedule of a working student and are accommodating to your schedule. You get to do your own school work when there is nothing to do.
cons: There is not much work to do. Simply put, they just need someone there to answer enquiries.

pros: Near MRT station, work-life balance, work with the brightest and driven world-class faculty, opportunity to grow within the organization and other NUS departments
cons: Too many red tapes, many restrictions in procurement, incapable finance department, horrible staff canteen, expensive food

pros: NUS gathers the best research fellows in the world. NUS supplied many things for researchers. There are many opportunities to meet seniors from other countries.
cons: Most researchers are from China. They usually work and live together. It is hard for foreigners to integrate into Chinese groups.

pros: strong branding, large fraternity and many potential linkages thro various stakeholders, strong education focused. Good work life benefits
cons: As a non academic, you would not be considered as priority. conservative thinking, and not open to new ideas. Lower than average salary, with no 13th month.

review_title: Great facilities, burn out is real
pros:
Great facilities 
Good funding
Colleagues are some of the best and brightest in their fields
cons: Constant pressure.  Publish or perish is real here, and since most research fellow contracts are yearly, there is a great amount of pressure to publish fast.

review_title: Out with the Old in with the New
pros: They used to have standards and actual integrity.
cons: There's change going on and while change is continuous and necessary, the way they are going about it is shameful. Staff are viewed as commodities to be squeezed dry.

pros: The only reason you would like to do postdoc is publishing papers. Go to a good team and publish. You will not be distracted by other things in NUS.
cons: Lower pay than working in the industry. Almost no chance to get a faculty position in NUS as a postdoc in NUS.

review_title: Not the worst but not the best either
pros:
-generally good work-life balance (though depends on which office you work in)
-relatively stable job
cons:
-uncompetitive salary for E&P
-declining compensations & benefits year by year)
-work with older colleagues who tend to have slower working pace than young ones

pros: my work hour is flexible, and stress level is manageable. also can access many facilities in school, which is quite nice. also school fee can be reduced if doing part-time master/phd as a staff
cons: work life balance may be subject to supervisors. (most of them are nice)

pros:
Nice environment: Trees, relaxed university atmosphere.
Benefits: 21 days annual leave (28 days after 10 years), family-friendly culture, cheap canteen food.
cons:
Lower pay, slow career progression.

NUS is very large, so it really depends where you work and the role you're holding. I'm satisfied with NUS, but dissatisfied with my boss!

review_title: good and time flexible for researchers
pros: time flexible and friendly working environment
cons: salary is not high, and some times too busy in deadline period...  Less attention on employer's family

review_title: the shortcomings and long-comings of working at NUS
pros: comfortable working environment; facilities of good quality, such as databases, library and so on; working with talent colleagues and group leaders.
cons: The space for self-development is limited and there is not so many training opportunities for employees like me to learn new knowledges

pros:
Good career outlook, highly ranked (number 1 in Asia)
Excellent research conditions
cons: Comparatively low salary, very little support for housing for research staff below faculty level

job_title: Research Engineer in Jurong West New Town,
pros: Good worklife balance. A good chance to explore research and academia. Good working environment.why i have to fill in 20 words? Stupid
cons: I do not have a single opinion about the cons. Why i have to write 20 20 20 ..... Words to submit this is so ridiculous

review_title: One of the best universities in the world!
pros: Excellent research facilities, multidisciplinary domain experts all near you, good management
cons: Too pragmatic view about academic research

review_title: A lot of resources but no career progression
pros: As a NUS staff, you will be spoilt with the resources they have in terms of library access and softwares
cons: No career progression and it took months to get the confirmation from HR

pros: The working environment is very good, people are nice, and you can involve quite a number of activities. The working hour is very flexible.
cons: The salary at the National University of Singapore for research engineers is too low, the housing rent is high

pros: It is a good extension after Master study to continue the research. The research topic is quite relevant and the professors are quite nice. The university administration procedure is also very efficient.
cons: Actually no much to comment. I think the research life in NUS is good for researchers.

pros: A wide range of jobs to choose from, from helpers for events, logistics and library staff to teaching assistants and research helpers.
cons: The standard rate of 8.74 for students may be considered a bit low, and is limited to 16 hours per week during semester.

pros: Latest research topics being worked on. Highly challenging project work happenning in SOC in NUS. Good personal skills with superiors.
cons: No Bonus, No AWS, Only Basic Salary given. Also contract is usually given for one year. Should be suitable for a phD candidate.

pros: The working environment is good in general: modern facility, nice college. The work schedule is quite flexible.
cons: The welfare is not so good. No free tea and coffee break. The air-con doesn't work at weekend.

pros: Lots of facilities, networking and equipment. Local government funding is also very high and not difficult to obtain.
cons: Too much by the book for daily activities, some disgruntled "anti- foreigner" people esp more senior.

pros: Very Singaporean Culture, overall a good place to study. Love the campus as it is expanding With the building of UTOWN.
cons: Very competitive place. Must be prepared to handle the work stress of an asian university. Engineering faculty needs to listen to feedback from its students

pros: good, forward looking and dynamic university. hard working and helpful students and junior research staff. A lot of opportunity to explore neighboring countries
cons: Sometimes the weather can be unbearable. Indoor living with expenses for aircon, taxi. Hard to find place to relax and think

review_title: evaluation based on performance, relatively flexible working time
pros: relatively flexible working hour, nice working environment and 7 in-campus food center
cons: working environment varies much among different labs, better to make a visit before join

pros: 21 days of  leave
cons: People who are already good at what they are doing and wants to play politics, engage in gossips, no team work, too fast-paced, no time for adjustment, management is unhelpful

review_title: Great working environment and work/life balance at NUS
pros: Colleagues at the Research Division, Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences are very helpful and understanding. Flexible environment. Not strict in attire. Benefits are very good. Work/ life balance is very good.
cons: Depending on your position, bonuses may be modest.

pros: Flexible work hours. Many days of leave.
cons:
Minimal bonus. Performance based on bell curve. Procurement is very slow and regimental.

Your welfare depends a lot on your PI. In my case, there were lots of admin stuff to distract you from research. Also no clear career path as a post-doc.

review_title: Not a good place for long term plan
pros: The recruitment process is fast. You have all the privileges of the university
cons: Almost fixed salary. Poor management. Smarter people tend to leave the team as soon as they get PR.

review_title: Have potential to be the leader of Asia
pros: Best labs in the asia, all kinds of tools available if needed
cons: people take more conservative approach. Need to be more encouraging to try new ideas,

pros: Huge compound with lots of very affordable food and unbeatable transportation within the compound. Great staff benefits.
cons: Tonnes of paperwork given the amount of administrative work involved in procurement and multi-step processes. Rigid structure makes it unsuitable for a creative individual.

pros:
Flexible timing
Casual manner
Get to learn a ly of new skills
Great benefits
cons: Salary is not too high and bonus is poor unless you're a prof or senior management

pros:
- Good working environment
- Great people in my department and institute
cons:
- Very few staff benefits
- No bonus for research staff (12-mth package)
- A lot of bureaucratic red tape (HR and finance)

pros: It is a good environment to grow and study. Its timing is flexible, and you can learn new thing. I would recommend students or new graduate because it is a good experience.
cons: Not so many chances to be promoted.

pros: Some (not much) freedom in your research
cons: Low pay for RA position. Favor locals over foreigner, no meritocracy. Poorly maintained equipment.  Some instrument staffs are terrible,  both at skills and attitude. Too much red tape

pros: Work life balance, good bonus and  reasonable benefits
cons: Appraisal is based on rotation rather than performance

pros: There are some very good labs in cancer research.
cons: There is a lot of administrative work that the lab head or manager is tasked with. In US university labs, this admin work would normally be performed by the department as it is much more efficent.

review_title: It was an interesting cultural experience
pros: got to meet some great people during the course of my PhD
cons:
lot of politics in the department
not much employment opportunities after the end of the PhD

review_title: Great colleagues, a lot of freedom at work
pros: The pay was reasonable. I get a lot of freedom in managing my own work. I work with really nice and intelligent people.
cons: There's not a lot in career advancement since I was hired to work on a specific project.

pros: Good financial and time support for research and publishing.  students and colleagues are among the best and brightest in Asia.
cons: Extremely competitive to get in, and colleagues in some departments are not welcoming to foreigners . Need to negotiate ruthlessly before you enter.

job_title: Laboratory Technologist in Clementi New Town,
pros:
Good team mates
Attractive starting salary and benefits
Flexible working environment with reasonable deadlines
cons:
Stagnant opportunities
Resist to change attitude on more experienced colleagues
Low increment

pros:
One of the best universities in Asia.
Plenty of research opportunities.
Multi-cultural staff & students.
Good salary & other perks.
cons:
Disbalance in budget allocation. Some departments gets too much and others too less.
Accommodation not provided to all the staff.
Heavy work load.

pros: Can experience the front line knowledge, and there is quite good scientific environment
cons: Need to have more innovative and brilliant supervisors, Remuneration need to be improved a lot
